column1: The Bayeux Tapestry (UK:
column2: US: ; French: Tapisserie de Bayeux [tapisʁi də bajø] or La telle du conquest; Latin: Tapete Baiocense) is an embroidered cloth nearly 70 metres (230 ft) long and 50 centimetres (20 in) tall that depicts the events leading up to the Norman conquest of England concerning William
column3: Duke of Normandy
column4: and Harold
column5: Earl of Wessex
column6: later King of England
column7: and culminating in the Battle of Hastings. It is thought to date to the 11th century
column8: within a few years after the battle. It tells the story from the point of view of the conquering Normans but is now agreed to have been made in England.

column1: According to Sylvette Lemagnen
column2: conservator of the tapestry
column3: in her 2005 book La Tapisserie de Bayeux:

column1: The Bayeux tapestry is one of the supreme achievements of the Norman Romanesque .... Its survival almost intact over nine centuries is little short of miraculous ... Its exceptional length
column2: the harmony and freshness of its colours
column3: its exquisite workmanship
column4: and the genius of its guiding spirit combine to make it endlessly fascinating.

column1: The cloth consists of some seventy scenes
column2: many with Latin tituli
column3: embroidered on linen with coloured woollen yarns. It is likely that it was commissioned by Bishop Odo
column4: William's half-brother
column5: and made in England—not Bayeux—in the 1070s. In 1729 the hanging was rediscovered by scholars at a time when it was being displayed annually in Bayeux Cathedral. The tapestry is now exhibited at the Musée de la Tapisserie de Bayeux in Bayeux
column6: Normandy

column1: The designs on the Bayeux Tapestry are embroidered rather than woven
column2: so that it is not technically a tapestry. Nevertheless
column3: it has always been referred to as a tapestry until recent years when the name "Bayeux Embroidery" has gained ground among certain art historians.  It can be seen as a rare example of secular Romanesque art.  Tapestries adorned both churches and wealthy houses in Medieval Western Europe
column4: though at 0.5 by 68.38 metres (1.6 by 224.3 ft
column5: and apparently incomplete) the Bayeux Tapestry is exceptionally large.  Only the figures and decoration are embroidered
column6: on a background left plain
column7: which shows the subject very clearly and was necessary to cover large areas.

column1: == Origins ==
The earliest known written reference to the tapestry is a 1476 inventory of Bayeux Cathedral
column2: but its origins have been the subject of much speculation and controversy.

column1: French legend maintained the tapestry was commissioned and created by Queen Matilda
column2: William the Conqueror's wife
column3: and her ladies-in-waiting. Indeed
column4: in France
column5: it is occasionally known as "La Tapisserie de la Reine Mathilde" (Tapestry of Queen Matilda). However
column6: scholarly analysis in the 20th century concluded it was probably commissioned by William's half-brother
column7: Bishop Odo
column11: when William was absent in Normandy

column1: The reasons for the Odo commission theory include: 1) three of the bishop's followers mentioned in the Domesday Book appear on the tapestry; 2) it was found in Bayeux Cathedral
column2: built by Odo; and 3) it may have been commissioned at the same time as the cathedral's construction in the 1070s
column3: possibly completed by 1077 in time for display on the cathedral's dedication.

column1: Assuming Odo commissioned the tapestry
column2: it was probably designed and constructed in England by Anglo-Saxon artists (Odo's main power base being by then in Kent); the Latin text contains hints of Anglo-Saxon; other embroideries originate from England at this time; and the vegetable dyes can be found in cloth traditionally woven there. Howard B. Clarke has proposed that the designer of the tapestry was Scolland
column3: the abbot of St Augustine's Abbey in Canterbury
column4: because of his previous position as head of the scriptorium at Mont Saint-Michel (famed for its illumination)
column5: his travels to Trajan's Column
column6: and his connections to Wadard and Vital
column7: two individuals identified in the tapestry.  The actual physical work of stitching was most likely undertaken by female needleworkers. Anglo-Saxon needlework of the more detailed type known as Opus Anglicanum was famous across Europe.  It was perhaps commissioned for display in the hall of his palace and then bequeathed to the cathedral he built
column8: following the pattern of the documented but lost hanging of Byrhtnoth.Alternative theories exist. Carola Hicks has suggested it could possibly have been commissioned by Edith of Wessex
column9: widow of Edward the Confessor and sister of Harold.  Wolfgang Grape has challenged the consensus that the embroidery is Anglo-Saxon
column10: distinguishing between Anglo-Saxon and other Northern European techniques; Medieval material authority Elizabeth Coatsworth contradicted this: "The attempt to distinguish Anglo-Saxon from other Northern European embroideries before 1100 on the grounds of technique cannot be upheld on the basis of present knowledge." George Beech suggests the tapestry was executed at the Abbey of Saint-Florent de Saumur in the Loire Valley
column11: and says the detailed depiction of the Breton campaign argues for additional sources in France. Andrew Bridgeford has suggested that the tapestry was actually of English design and encoded with secret messages meant to undermine Norman rule.

column1: == Construction
column2: design and technique ==

column1: In common with other embroidered hangings of the early medieval period
column2: this piece is conventionally referred to as a "tapestry"
column3: although it is not a true tapestry in which the design is woven into the cloth; it is in fact an embroidery.

column1: The Bayeux tapestry is embroidered in crewel (wool yarn) on a tabby-woven linen ground 68.38 metres long and 0.5 metres wide (224.3 ft × 1.6 ft) and using two methods of stitching: outline or stem stitch for lettering and the outlines of figures
column2: and couching or laid work for filling in figures. Nine linen panels
column3: between fourteen and three metres in length
column4: were sewn together after each was embroidered and the joins were disguised with subsequent embroidery. At the first join (start of scene 14) the borders do not line up properly but the technique was improved so that the later joins are practically invisible. The design involved a broad central zone with narrow decorative borders top and bottom. By inspecting the woollen threads behind the linen it is apparent all these aspects were embroidered together at a session and the awkward placing of the tituli is not due to them being added later. Later generations have patched the hanging in numerous places and some of the embroidery (especially in the final scene) has been reworked. The tapestry may well have maintained much of its original appearance—it now compares closely with a careful drawing made in 1730.The end of the tapestry has been missing from time immemorial and the final titulus "Et fuga verterunt Angli" ("and the English left fleeing") is said to be "entirely spurious"
column5: added shortly before 1814 at a time of anti-English sentiment. Musset  speculates the hanging was originally about 1.5 metres longer. At the last section still remaining the embroidery has been almost completely restored but this seems to have been done with at least some regard to the original stitching. The stylised tree is quite unlike any other tree in the tapestry. The start of the tapestry has also been restored but to a much lesser extent.Norton has reviewed the various measurements of the length of the tapestry itself and of its nine individual linen panels. He has also attempted to estimate the size and architectural design of the 11th-century Bayeux Cathedral. He considers the tapestry would have fitted well if it had been hung along the south
column6: west and north arcades of the nave and that the scenes it depicts can be correlated with positions of the arcade bays in a way that would have been dramatically satisfying. He agrees with earlier speculation that a final panel is missing—one that shows William's coronation and which he thinks was some three metres long. Norton concludes that the tapestry was definitely designed to be hung in Bayeux Cathedral specifically; that it was designed to appeal to a Norman audience; and that it was probably designed for Bishop Odo so as to be displayed at the dedication of the cathedral in 1077 in the presence of William
column7: Matilda
column9: and Odo.The main yarn colours are terracotta or russet
column14: with small amounts of dark blue or black and sage green. Later repairs are worked in light yellow
column16: and light greens. Laid yarns are couched in place with yarn of the same or contrasting colour.

column1: The tapestry's central zone contains most of the action
column2: which sometimes overflows into the borders either for dramatic effect or because depictions would otherwise be very cramped (for example at Edward's death scene). Events take place in a long series of scenes which are generally separated by highly stylised trees. However
column3: the trees are not placed consistently and the greatest scene shift
column4: between Harold's audience with Edward after his return to England and Edward's burial scene
column5: is not marked in any way at all.The tituli are normally in the central zone but occasionally use the top border. The borders are otherwise mostly purely decorative and only sometimes does the decoration complement the action in the central zone. The decoration consists of birds
column6: beasts
column7: fish and scenes from fables
column9: and hunting. There are frequent oblique bands separating the vignettes. There are nude figures
column11: others of a ribald nature. A harrow
column13: is depicted (scene 10) and this is the earliest known depiction. The picture of Halley's Comet
column14: which appears in the upper border (scene 32)
column15: is the first known picture of this comet.In 1724 a linen backing cloth was sewn on comparatively crudely and
column17: large ink numerals were written on the backing which broadly enumerate each scene and which are still commonly used for reference.

column1: == Background to the events depicted ==
In a series of pictures supported by a written commentary the tapestry tells the story of the events of 1064–1066 culminating in the Battle of Hastings. The two main protagonists are Harold Godwinson
column2: recently crowned King of England
column3: leading the Anglo-Saxon English
column4: and William
column5: Duke of Normandy
column6: leading a mainly Norman army
column7: sometimes called the companions of William the Conqueror.

column1: William was the illegitimate son of Robert the Magnificent
column2: Duke of Normandy
column3: and Herleva (or Arlette)
column4: a tanner's daughter. William became Duke of Normandy at the age of seven and was in control of Normandy by the age of nineteen. His half-brother was Bishop Odo of Bayeux.

column1: King Edward the Confessor
column2: king of England and about sixty years old at the time the tapestry starts its narration
column3: had no children or any clear successor. Edward's mother
column4: Emma of Normandy
column5: was William's great aunt. At that time succession to the English throne was not by primogeniture but was decided jointly by the king and by an assembly of nobility
column6: the Witenagemot.

column1: Harold Godwinson
column2: Earl of Wessex and the most powerful noble in England
column3: was Edward's brother-in-law. The Norman chronicler William of Poitiers reported that Edward had previously determined that William would succeed him on the throne
column4: and Harold had sworn to honour this
column5: and yet later that Harold had claimed Edward
column6: on his deathbed
column7: had made him heir over William. However
column9: such as Eadmer dispute this claim.

column1: == Events depicted in the tapestry ==

The tapestry begins with a panel of Edward the Confessor sending Harold to Normandy.(scene 1) Later Norman sources say that the mission was for Harold to pledge loyalty to William but the tapestry does not suggest any specific purpose. By mischance
column2: Harold arrives at the wrong location in France and is taken prisoner by Guy
column3: Count of Ponthieu.(scene 7) After exchanges of messages borne by mounted messengers
column4: Harold is released to William who then invites Harold to accompany him on a campaign against Conan II
column5: Duke of Brittany. On the way
column6: just outside the monastery of Mont Saint-Michel
column7: the army become mired in quicksand and Harold saves two Norman soldiers.(scene 17) William's army chases Conan from Dol de Bretagne to Rennes
column8: and Conan finally surrenders at Dinan.(scene 20) William gives Harold arms and armour (possibly knighting him) and Harold takes an oath on saintly relics.(scene 23) Although the writing on the tapestry explicitly states an oath is taken there is no clue as to what is being promised.Harold leaves for home and meets again with the old king Edward
column9: who appears to be remonstrating with him.(scene 25) Harold is in a somewhat submissive posture and seems to be in disgrace. However
column11: the king's intentions are not made clear. The scene then shifts by about one year to when Edward has become mortally ill and the tapestry strongly suggests that
column13: he bequeaths the crown to Harold. What is probably the coronation ceremony is attended by Stigand
column14: whose position as Archbishop of Canterbury was controversial.(scene 31) Stigand is performing a liturgical function
column15: possibly not the crowning itself. The tapestry labels the celebrant as "Stigant Archieps" (Stigand the archbishop) although by that time he had been excommunicated by the papacy who considered his appointment unlawful.

column1: A star with a streaming tail
column2: probably Halley's Comet
column3: then appears. At this point
column4: the lower border of the tapestry shows a fleet of ghost-like ships thus hinting at a future invasion.(scene 33) The news of Harold's coronation is taken to Normandy
column5: whereupon we are told that William is ordering a fleet of ships to be built although it is Bishop Odo shown issuing the instructions.(scene 35) The invaders reach England
column6: and land unopposed. William orders his men to find food
column7: and a meal is cooked.(scene 43) A house is burnt by two soldiers
column8: which may indicate some ravaging of the local countryside on the part of the invaders
column10: on a smaller scale than the arsonists
column11: a woman holds her boy's hand as she asks for humanity.(scene 47) News is brought to William. The Normans build a motte and bailey at Hastings to defend their position. Messengers are sent between the two armies
column12: and William makes a speech to prepare his army for battle.(scene 51)

column1: The Battle of Hastings was fought on 14 October 1066 less than three weeks after the Battle of Stamford Bridge but the tapestry does not provide this context. The English fight on foot behind a shield wall
column2: whilst the Normans are on horses. Two fallen knights are named as Leofwine and Gyrth
column3: Harold's brothers
column4: but both armies are shown fighting bravely. Bishop Odo brandishes his baton or mace and rallies the Norman troops in battle.(scene 54) To reassure his knights that he is still alive and well
column5: William raises his helmet to show his face. The battle becomes very bloody with troops being slaughtered and dismembered corpses littering the ground. King Harold is killed.(scene 57) This scene can be interpreted in different ways
column6: as the name "Harold" appears above a number of knights
column7: making it difficult to identify which character is Harold
column8: since one character appears with an arrow shot in his head under the name "Harold" while another character is slain by a sword underneath the words "he is slain". The final remaining scene shows unarmoured English troops fleeing the battlefield. The last part of the tapestry is missing; however
column9: it is thought that the story contained only one additional scene.

column1: == Latin text ==

Tituli are included in many scenes to point out names of people and places or to explain briefly the event being depicted. The text is in Latin but at times the style of words and spelling shows an English influence. A dark blue wool
column2: almost black
column3: is mostly used but towards the end of the tapestry other colours are used
column4: sometimes for each word and other times for each letter. The complete text and English translation are displayed beside images of each scene at Bayeux Tapestry tituli.

column1: == Recorded history ==

The first reference to the tapestry is from 1476 when it was listed in an inventory of the treasures of Bayeux Cathedral. It survived the sack of Bayeux by the Huguenots in 1562; and the next certain reference is from 1724. Antoine Lancelot sent a report to the Académie Royale des Inscriptions et Belles-Lettres concerning a sketch he had received about a work concerning William the Conqueror. He had no idea where or what the original was
column2: although he suggested it could have been a tapestry. Despite further enquiries he discovered no more.

column1: The Benedictine scholar Bernard de Montfaucon made more successful investigations and found that the sketch was of a small portion of a tapestry preserved at Bayeux Cathedral. In 1729 and 1730 he published drawings and a detailed description of the complete work in the first two volumes of his Les Monuments de la Monarchie française. The drawings were by Antoine Benoît
column2: one of the ablest draughtsmen of that time.The tapestry was first briefly noted in English in 1743 by William Stukeley
column3: in his Palaeographia Britannica. The first detailed account in English was written by Smart Lethieullier
column4: who was living in Paris in 1732–3
column5: and was acquainted with Lancelot and de Montfaucon: it was not published
column6: however
column7: until 1767
column8: as an appendix to Andrew Ducarel's Anglo-Norman Antiquities.During the French Revolution
column10: the tapestry was confiscated as public property to be used for covering military wagons. It was rescued from a wagon by a local lawyer who stored it in his house until the troubles were over
column11: whereupon he sent it to the city administrators for safekeeping. After the Terror the Fine Arts Commission
column12: set up to safeguard national treasures in 1803
column13: required it to be removed to Paris for display at the Musée Napoléon. When Napoleon abandoned his planned invasion of Britain the tapestry's propaganda value was lost and it was returned to Bayeux where the council displayed it on a winding apparatus of two cylinders. Despite scholars' concern that the tapestry was becoming damaged the council refused to return it to the cathedral.

column1: In 1816 the Society of Antiquaries of London commissioned its historical draughtsman
column2: Charles Stothard
column3: to visit Bayeux to make an accurate hand-coloured facsimile of the tapestry. His drawings were subsequently engraved by James Basire jr. and published by the Society in 1819–23. Stothard's images are still of value as a record of the tapestry as it was before 19th-century restoration.

column1: By 1842 the tapestry was displayed in a special-purpose room in the Bibliothèque Publique. It required special storage in 1870 with the threatened invasion of Normandy in the Franco-Prussian War and again in 1939–1944 by the Ahnenerbe during the German occupation of France and the Normandy landings. On 27 June 1944 the Gestapo took the tapestry to the Louvre and on 18 August
column2: three days before the Wehrmacht withdrew from Paris
column3: Himmler sent a message (intercepted by Bletchley Park) ordering it to be taken to "a place of safety"
column4: thought to be Berlin. It was only on 22 August that the SS attempted to take possession of the tapestry
column5: by which time the Louvre was again in French hands. After the liberation of Paris
column6: on 25 August
column7: the tapestry was again put on public display in the Louvre
column8: and in 1945 it was returned to Bayeux
column9: where it is exhibited at the Musée de la Tapisserie de Bayeux.

column1: == Later reputation and history ==
The inventory listing of 1476 shows that the tapestry was being hung annually in Bayeux Cathedral for the week of the Feast of St John the Baptist; and this was still the case in 1728
column2: although by that time the purpose was merely to air the hanging
column3: which was otherwise stored in a chest. Clearly
column4: the work was being well cared for. In the eighteenth century
column5: the artistry was regarded as crude or even barbarous—red and yellow multi-coloured horses upset some critics. It was thought to be unfinished because the linen was not covered with embroidery. However
column6: its exhibition in the Louvre in 1797 caused a sensation
column7: with Le Moniteur
column8: which normally dealt with foreign affairs
column9: reporting on it on its first two pages. It inspired a popular musical
column10: La Tapisserie de la Reine Mathilde. It was because the tapestry was regarded as an antiquity rather than a work of art that in 1804 it was returned to Bayeux
column13: reported that "there is a sort of purity in its primitive forms
column14: especially considering the state of the arts in the eleventh century".The tapestry was becoming a tourist attraction
column15: with Robert Southey complaining of the need to queue to see the work. In the 1843 Hand-book for Travellers in France by John Murray III
column16: a visit was included on "Recommended Route 26 (Caen to Cherbourg via Bayeux)"
column17: and this guidebook led John Ruskin to go there; he would describe the tapestry as "the most interesting thing in its way conceivable". Charles Dickens
column19: was not impressed: "It is certainly the work of amateurs; very feeble amateurs at the beginning and very heedless some of them too."During the Second World War Heinrich Himmler coveted the work
column20: regarding it as "important for our glorious and cultured Germanic history".In 2018
column21: French President Emmanuel Macron announced that the Bayeux Tapestry would be loaned to Britain for public display. It is expected to be exhibited at the British Museum in London
column22: but not before 2020. It will be the first time that it has left France in 950 years.

column1: == Mysteries ==
The depiction of events on the tapestry raises several mysteries:

The identification of Harold II of England in the vignette depicting his death is disputed. Some recent historians disagree with the traditional view that Harold is the figure struck in the eye with an arrow. The view that it is Harold is supported by the fact that the words Harold Rex (King Harold) appear right above the figure's head. However
column2: the arrow is a later addition following a period of repair
column3: as can be seen by comparison with Bernard de Montfaucon's engravings of the tapestry as it was in 1729
column4: in which the arrow is absent (see illustration above). However
column5: needle holes in the linen do suggest that something had originally been in the place of the arrow
column6: though it may have been a lance rather than an arrow. A figure is slain with a sword in the subsequent plate
column7: and the phrase above the figure refers to Harold's death (interfectus est
column8: "he is slain"). This would appear to be more consistent with the labeling used elsewhere in the work. It was common medieval iconography that a perjurer was to die with a weapon through the eye. Therefore
column9: the tapestry might be said to emphasize William's rightful claim to the throne by depicting Harold as an oath breaker. Whether he actually died in this way remains a mystery and is much debated.

column1: There is a panel with what appears to be a clergyman touching or possibly striking a woman's face. No one knows the significance of this scene or the caption above it: ubi unus clericus et Ælfgyva ("where [or in which] a certain cleric and Ælfgyva")
column2: where Ælfgyva is the Latinised spelling of Ælfgifu
column3: a popular Anglo-Saxon woman's name (literally "elf-gift"). The use of the grapheme Æ shows familiarity with English spelling. There are two naked male figures in the border below this figure; the one directly below the figure is in a pose mirroring that of the cleric
column4: squatting and displaying his genitalia (a scene that was frequently censored in historical reproductions). However
column5: similar naked figures appear elsewhere in the lower border where there seems to be no connection at all with the main action. Harold had a younger sister named Ælfgifu (her name is spelt Alveva in the Domesday book) who was possibly promised to William by Harold or even betrothed to him
column6: but she died c. 1066
column7: prior to the invasion. Ælfgifu was also the name of the mother of Sweyn Knutsson and Harold Harefoot
column8: past kings of Denmark and England respectively
column9: via Cnut the Great. It has been speculated that this scene
column10: occurring after the meeting of Harold and William
column11: is to remind the contemporary viewers of a scandal that occurred between Ælfgifu of Northampton and Emma of Normandy
column13: that eventually led to the crowning of Edward the Confessor

column1: At least two panels of the tapestry are missing
column2: perhaps even another 6.4 m (7.0 yd) in total. This missing area may have included William's coronation.

column1: == Reliability ==
The Bayeux Tapestry was probably commissioned by the House of Normandy and essentially depicts a Norman viewpoint. However
column2: Harold is shown as brave
column3: and his soldiers are not belittled. Throughout
column4: William is described as dux ("duke")
column5: whereas Harold
column6: also called dux up to his coronation
column7: is subsequently called rex ("king"). The fact that the narrative extensively covers Harold's activities in Normandy (in 1064) indicates that the intention was to show a strong relationship between that expedition and the Norman Conquest starting two years later. It is for this reason that the tapestry is generally seen by modern scholars as an apologia for the Norman Conquest.

column1: The tapestry's narration seems to place stress on Harold's oath to William
column2: although its rationale is not made clear. Norman sources claim that the English succession was being pledged to William
column3: but English sources give varied accounts. Today it is thought that the Norman sources are to be preferred. Both the tapestry and Norman sources name Stigand
column4: the excommunicated archbishop of Canterbury
column5: as the man who crowned Harold
column6: possibly to discredit Harold's kingship; one English source suggests that he was crowned by Ealdred
column7: archbishop of York
column9: making Harold's position as legitimate king more secure. Contemporary scholarship has not decided the matter
column10: although it is generally thought that Ealdred performed the coronation.Although political propaganda or personal emphasis may have somewhat distorted the historical accuracy of the story
column11: the Bayeux Tapestry constitutes a visual record of medieval arms
column13: and other objects unlike any other artifact surviving from this period. There is no attempt at continuity between scenes
column14: either in individuals' appearance or clothing. The knights carry shields
column15: but show no system of hereditary coats of arms—the beginnings of modern heraldic structure were in place
column16: but would not become standard until the middle of the 12th century. It has been noted that the warriors are depicted fighting with bare hands
column17: while other sources indicate the general use of gloves in battle and hunt.

column1: American historian Stephen D. White
column2: in a study of the tapestry
column3: has "cautioned against reading it as an English or Norman story
column4: showing how the animal fables visible in the borders may instead offer a commentary on the dangers of conflict and the futility of pursuing power".

column1: == Artistic context ==

Tapestry fragments have been found in Scandinavia dating from the ninth century and it is thought that Norman and Anglo-Saxon embroidery developed from this sort of work. Examples are to be found in the grave goods of the Oseberg ship and the Överhogdal tapestries.A monastic text from Ely
column2: the Liber Eliensis
column3: mentions a woven narrative wall-hanging commemorating the deeds of Byrhtnoth
column4: killed in 991. Wall-hangings were common by the tenth century with English and Norman texts particularly commending the skill of Anglo-Saxon seamstresses. Mural paintings imitating draperies still exist in France and Italy and there are twelfth-century mentions of other wall-hangings in Normandy and France. A poem by Baldric of Dol might even describe the Bayeux Tapestry itself. The Bayeux Tapestry was therefore not unique at the time it was created: rather it is remarkable for being the sole surviving example of medieval narrative needlework.

column1: == Replicas and continuations ==
A number of replicas of the Bayeux Tapestry have been created.
Through the collaboration of William Morris with textile manufacturer Thomas Wardle
column2: Wardle's wife Elizabeth
column3: who was an accomplished seamstress
column4: embarked on creating a reproduction in 1885. She organised some 37 women in her Leek School of Art Embroidery to collaborate working from a full-scale water-colour facsimile drawing provided by the South Kensington Museum. The full-size replica was finished in 1886 and is now exhibited in Reading Museum in Reading
column5: Berkshire
column6: England. The naked figure in the original tapestry (in the border below the Ælfgyva figure) is depicted wearing a brief garment because the drawing which was worked from was similarly bowdlerised.

column1: Ray Dugan of University of Waterloo
column2: Ontario
column3: Canada
column4: completed a stitched replica in 1996. Since its completion
column5: it has been displayed in various museums and galleries in Canada and the United States.

column2: the Danish-based Bayeux Group
column3: part of the Viking Group Lindholm Høje
column4: began making an accurate replica of the Bayeux Tapestry
column5: using the original sewing techniques. The replica was completed in June 2014 and went on permanent exhibition at Børglum Abbey in May 2015.

column1: Dr. E. D. Wheeler
column2: former judge and former dean at Oglethorpe University
column3: commissioned a hand-painted
column4: full-size replica of the Bayeux Tapestry completed by Margaret ReVille and donated it to the University of West Georgia in Carrollton in 1994. In 2014
column5: the replica was acquired by the University of North Georgia in Dahlonega.

column1: An approximately half scale mosaic version of the Bayeux Tapestry was formerly on display at Geraldine
column2: New Zealand. It was made up of 1.5 million 7 mm2 pieces of spring steel—off-cuts from patterning disks of knitting machines—and was created by Michael Linton over a period of twenty years from 1979. The work was in 32 sections
column3: and included a hypothetical reconstruction of the missing final section leading up to William the Conqueror's coronation at Westminster Abbey on Christmas Day

column1: Jason Welch
column2: a woodcarver from North Creake
column3: Norfolk
column4: England
column5: created a replica of the tapestry between 2011 and 2014 in carved and painted wooden relief on 25 five-foot planks. He undertook the project to help cope with the grief of losing his 18-year-old son.Lazzari
column6: Adam (14 January 2014). "Photo gallery: Norfolk man creates a 135ft wooden version of the Bayeux Tapestry to help cope with his son's death". Dereham Times. Retrieved 15 June 2020.

column1: Mia Hansson
column2: from Skanör
column3: Sweden
column4: living in Wisbech
column5: Isle of Ely
column6: Cambridgeshire
column7: started a reproduction on 13 July 2016. As of December 2019 she had completed 22 metres
column8: saying that she expected to finish in some 7 years. Hansson takes part of her replica out for talk and display events.Other modern artists have attempted to complete the work by creating panels depicting subsequent events up to William's coronation
column9: though the actual content of the missing panels is unknown. In 1997
column10: the embroidery artist Jan Messent completed a reconstruction showing William accepting the surrender of English nobles at Berkhamsted (Beorcham)
column13: 416 residents of Alderney in the Channel Islands finished a continuation including William's coronation and the building of the Tower of London.

column1: == In popular culture ==
Because it resembles a modern comic strip or movie storyboard
column2: is widely recognised
column3: and is so distinctive in its artistic style
column4: the Bayeux Tapestry has frequently been used or reimagined in a variety of different popular culture contexts. George Wingfield Digby wrote in 1957:

column1: It was designed to tell a story to a largely illiterate public; it is like a strip cartoon
column2: racy
column3: emphatic
column4: colourful
column5: with a good deal of blood and thunder and some ribaldry.

column1: It has been cited by Scott McCloud in Understanding Comics as an example of early sequential-narrative art; and Bryan Talbot
column2: a British comic book artist
column3: has called it "the first known British comic strip".It has inspired many modern political and other cartoons
column4: including:

column1: John Hassall's satirical pastiche Ye Berlyn Tapestrie
column2: published in 1915
column3: which tells the story of the German invasion of Belgium in August 1914

column1: Rea Irvin's cover for the New Yorker magazine of 15 July 1944 marking D-Day
George Gale's pastiche chronicling the saga leading up to Britain's entry into the European Economic Community
column2: published across six pages in The Times's "Europa" supplement on 1 January 1973The tapestry has inspired modern embroideries
column3: most notably and directly:

column1: The Overlord Embroidery (1974)
column2: commemorating Operation Overlord and the Normandy landings of 1944
column3: now at Portsmouth

column1: The Prestonpans Tapestry (2010)
column2: which chronicles the events surrounding the Battle of Prestonpans in 1745Other embroideries more loosely inspired by it include the Hastings Embroidery (1966)
column3: the New World Tapestry (1980–2000)
column4: the Quaker Tapestry (1981–89)
column5: the Great Tapestry of Scotland (2013)
column6: the Scottish Diaspora Tapestry (2014–15)
column7: Magna Carta (An Embroidery) (2014–15)
column8: and (in this case a true woven tapestry) the Game of Thrones Tapestry (2017).

column1: A number of films have used sections of the tapestry in their opening credits or closing titles
column2: including Disney's Bedknobs and Broomsticks
column3: Anthony Mann's El Cid
column4: Franco Zeffirelli's Hamlet
column5: Frank Cassenti's La Chanson de Roland
column6: Kevin Reynolds' Robin Hood: Prince of Thieves
column7: and Richard Fleischer's The Vikings.The design and embroidery of the tapestry form one of the narrative strands of Marta Morazzoni's 1988 novella The Invention of Truth.

column1: The tapestry is referred to in Tony Kushner's play Angels in America. The apocryphal account of Queen Matilda's creation of the tapestry is used
column2: perhaps in order to demonstrate that Louis
column3: one of the main characters
column4: holds himself to mythological standards.
